The '''meibomian glands''' (or '''tarsal glands''') are a special kind of [[sebaceous glands]] at the rim of the [[eyelid]]s inside the tarsal plate, responsible for the supply of meibum, an oily substance that prevents evaporation of the [[eye]]'s [[Tears|tear]] film, prevents tear spillage onto the cheek, makes the closed lids airtight and acts as a blockade for tear fluid, trapping tears between the oiled edge and eyeball.<ref>"eye, human." EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica. Encyclopaedia Britannica Ultimate Reference Suite. Chicago: EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica, 2010.</ref> There are approximately 50 glands on the upper eyelids and 25 glands on the lower eyelids.

The '''meibomian glands''' (or '''tarsal glands''') are a special kind of [[sebaceous glands]] at the rim of the [[eyelid]]s inside the tarsal plate, responsible for the supply of meibum, an oily substance that prevents evaporation of the [[eye]]'s [[Tears|tear]] film, prevents tear spillage onto the cheek, makes the closed lids airtight and acts as a blockade for tear fluid, trapping tears between the oiled edge and eyeball.<ref>"eye, human." EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica. [[Encyclopaedia Britannica Ultimate Reference Suite]]. Chicago: EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica, 2010.</ref> There are approximately 50 glands on the upper eyelids and 25 glands on the lower eyelids.
The glands are named after [[Heinrich Meibom (doctor)|Heinrich Meibom]] (1638-1700), a German physician.
The glands are named after [[Heinrich Meibom (doctor)|Heinrich Meibom]] (1638-1700), a German physician.
